photo.description: One of many interesting looking windows. There is intricate detail around each window of the inner courtyard Kronborg Castle, which was the setting for Shakespeare's Hamlet. I will need to learn about the symbolism that's on display here.

photo.description: Hamlet's castle
photo.tags: scandinavia helsingor kronborgslot denmark
photo.title: Kronborg Slot

photo.description: ...to play hamlet. as in all real castles, there is only one way in and true to his cool, jude law arrived on foot and walked leisurely past the teenage girls of all ages who were awaiting his arrival - oh, and past me, of course, though I was there less for law and more to get the best seats for the play. and we did get the best seats, sat right next to the new minister of culture who has yet to prove herself but who is already much loved for not being the old one - a living, breathing nightmare of a politician now running the justice department...talk about something rotten... the castle kronborg is of course the site of shakespeare's hamlet and there is a tradition for inviting english theatre companies to perform that very play in the courtyard. all the great hamlets of the 20th century have played there: olivier, guilgud, richard burton, derek jacoby, kenneth branagh - I have missed all of them, mostly through not having been born. law we didn't miss and even if I doubt he'll join the ranks of the best of them, we enjoyed it and him tremendously. kronborg won a place in theatre history - and in architecture too - when rain forced tyrone guthrie's 1937 direction of laurence olivier, vivien leigh and alec guinness indoors, and they improvised a propless, open stage performance - effectly rediscovering shakespeare's thrust stage for our time. it has been hated by actors ever since but is much loved by architects, I believe, for bringing the actors into the space of the audience and vice versa. tonight's performance was old school proscenium, but its minimalist style - one black set, all words, no props - and jude law's athletic hamlet would have worked well on guthrie's thrust stage. while waiting, I thought there was a comedic aspect to all these women who wanted jude law but who would have to sit through 3 or 4 hours of shakespeare. in the end, all came out smiling as they had been given jude law enlarged by shakespeare - and, as one of them noticed, law wasn't very big to begin with.
photo.tags: jude law hamlet shakespeare kronborg castle elsinore helsingør denmark danmark
photo.title: jude law arrives at the castle in elsinore...
